fields.name: Hot Water
fields.content: Many of us don't realize that using water uses energy. In fact, supplying your home with hot water uses a lot of energy. Your hot water tank has to keep around 60 gallons of water at more than 100°F all day long. Hot water accounts for about 15% of the average household’s energy bill."Where Does My Money Go?" ENERGY STAR. n.d. 19 Jan 2010 By becoming more aware of your hot water use, and installing a few low-cost upgrades, you can easily reduce this number. The following steps will help you be more mindful and use your hot water more efficiently.
fields.teaser: Hot water accounts for about 15-20% of the average household’s energy bill. By becoming more aware of your hot water use, and installing a few low-cost upgrades, you can easily reduce this number.

fields.name: Electricity
fields.content: You may already be taking steps like turning off the lights when you leave a room, but some sources of electricity waste are more difficult to spot. These actions will help you maximize your electricity savings by identifying these sources.

fields.name: Air Sealing & Insulation
fields.content: While improving your home's heating and cooling system is important, you'll see the biggest improvements by focusing on air sealing and insulation. Typical homeowners can save up to 10% on their total energy bills by adding appropriate air sealing and insulation.ENERGY STAR, "Methodology for Estimated Energy Savings from Cost-Effective Air Sealing and Insulating." n.d. 23 Feb 2010 In addition to lowering energy bills, proper air sealing and insulation will also create a healthier home with better air quality and fewer allergens. "Air sealing" refers to closing gaps in a house, preventing unwanted drafts and air leakage. "Insulation" is a material that limits heat flow. Insulation is like putting on a sweater; air sealing is like zipping up your coat. As you know from walking outside on a cold day, the warmest coat is almost useless if it's left open. The same is true in your home: installing insulation should go hand-in-hand with improved air sealing.

fields.name: Heating & Cooling
fields.content: Your heating and cooling system is the single biggest contributor to your home's overall energy bill."Where Does My Money Go?" ENERGY STAR. n.d. 19 Jan. 2010 While buying new equipment may make sense for some older, out-of-date systems, these upgrades can be quite pricey. Instead of investing in expensive improvements, you can see big savings simply by getting the most out of the equipment already in your home. These low- and no-cost steps will give you a big return on your investment and significantly reduce your energy use.

fields.name: Appliances
fields.content: Appliances - like your refrigerator, dish washer, and clothes dryer - account for 13% of the average home's energy bill."Where Does My Money Go?" ENERGY STAR. n.d. 19 Jan. 2010 These actions will help you use your appliances more efficiently and decide whether it's time to upgrade to a newer model.

fields.name: Home Audits
fields.content: Having a home audits will improve your home's re-sale value, lower your utility bills, and create a more comfortable living space. After having an audit and making improvements, the average household saves more than 20% on their total energy bill."Maryland Home Performance with ENERGY STAR." Maryland Energy Administration. n.d. 20 Jan, 2010 Some households have the potential to save as much as 40%."In Maryland, annual residential energy costs average $2400 per year. With the Maryland Home Performance with ENERGY STAR Program, potential exists to save between $200 and $950 per year by making the home more energy-efficient." "Maryland Home Performance with ENERGY STAR." Maryland Energy Administration. n.d. 20 Jan, 2010 Working with an auditor is the single biggest step you can take towards improving the overall performance of your home.
